reviewText: My wife and I bought the first season based on the amazing number of five-star reviews here.  We definitely regret doing so.  We haven't found much of anything to enjoy so far in this first season--the scripts are derivative and repetitive, the dialogue is trivial and uninspired, and many of the situations are just simply silly--they require far too much suspension of disbelief in order to buy what's going on.  We both love the premise and hoped for more, but we didn't get it.  The feeling I get is that the makers are trying too hard with everything, including casting.  Nothing seems natural, and everything seems forced, with a "this will work here" feeling behind it all.And while the main character seems to be created to be confused and overwhelmed, she comes across mostly as whiny--and her voice for the narrative voiceovers is simply ineffective.  And while I don't have any problem with vulgarity if it fits in the context of the show, here the curse words seem nothing more than gratuitous.  And much of what goes on seems contrived in order to create confusion that allows for plot twists, such as giving only the initials of the people who are going to die.  It's a contrivance that makes no sense at all, and that is also fairly insulting to a viewer's intelligence.  And the dead having bodies and having to eat and have jobs?  This is another contrivance that allows them to put the main character in a dead-end office job that is one of the most lifeless and boring settings that I've ever seen.It's interesting for a couple of episodes, but our interest died out quickly, and we don't feel any desire at all to see the rest of the season.  We don't care about any of the characters, and we don't care about what will happen to them--it'll more than likely be more of the same.

reviewText: No TV series has ever elevated sub-genre "black comedy" like "Dead Like Me," a seriously funny, often poignant examination of death and - therefore - life.  Cable TV has given birth to many terrific dramatic series - "The Sopranos," "The Wire," "Deadwood," "Rome," etc.  But there haven't been nearly as many hallowed comedies - proof that comedy is darn hard.  "Dead Like Me" attempts to balance the scales.George (Ellen Muth) is a typical slacker - she lives at home with her dysfunctional family, interested in nothing and nobody.  She gets stuck in a dead-end job doing filing/data entry when she is killed on her first lunch break by a toilet seat falling from a Russian space station.It only gets better from there.George's soul is met by Rube (the incomparable Mandy Patinkin), who lays out the new rules:  George is a Grim Reaper.  Her job is to take souls from the newly-departed and escort them to their final destination, whatever that may be.  In a lesser series, George would shrug and the stories would focus on the conflict between her slacker-ness and her new job.  While there is some of that humor, the story quickly becomes much deeper as George comes to terms with the life she has led and the life she still has to lead.Still has to lead?  That's right. Grim Reapers are part of the everyday world - they need to work or steal to pay the bills.  And so it is that George finds herself back in the corporate trenches, where she learns more about life after dying than she did before.There are too many perfect moments and perfect casting choices here to mention, so I'll only allude to the highlights.  The pilot episode hits stratospheric heights with George's first "job," to take the soul of an innocent little girl who is scheduled to die - George resists it, naturally, but the show takes this plot point in a delightfully sad, touching way.  Let's just say the Portland's own Pink Martini's rendition of "Que Sera Sera" will never be put to better use.And any actress who claims that there are no good roles for overweight women over 35 have completely ignored Christine Willes' brilliant performance as the zany, uptight Delores Herbig - one part Nurse Ratchet and three parts crazy Aunt Flo.  All the actors do great work here, including Cynthia Stevenson as George's uptight, grieving mom Joy (perfect name!), Callum Blue as a British stoner-Grim Reaper, and Jasmine Guy, who leaves "A Diff'rent World" far, far behind.Solid writing, impeccable comic timing, and more than its fair share of insight and wisdom make Season One of "Dead Like Me" one of the best TV seasons ever.  Quite simply, a must-see.

reviewText: The "other" dead show?  What a perverse perspective.  In my opinion, this is easily the best series I have watched.  It works on every level -  it is smart, poignant, funny, sad, profound, unpredictable, and amazingly entertaining.  The actors and actresses are very well cast, and the plots are never boring.  The characters are very believable, and the dry, smart humor never goes into the predictable cliches that have become the staple of most sitcoms.This show is so funny and moving, often at the same time, it becomes difficult to even watch other shows.  It also dances along the delicate line of having a message without being preachy.  The dialogue is superb, spoken with perfect timing by excellent actors.  Callum Blue and Ellen Muth could make an ill-humored mailbox laugh, although that could probably said to a lesser degree about all the actors in the show.If you are sick of bland, derivative, childish sitcoms, then get this DVD.  I can not imagine anyone being disappointed in it.This is an addendum to my initial review.  Recently, I had someone visit from Florida who I wanted to show this series to.  She showed absolutely no interest in it, despite my telling her how incredible this series was. She was very reluctant to watch even one show, but I knew she would like it so I persisted in trying.  Eventually I managed to get her to watch an episode.  After that, whenever she would come over she would ask to see more and each night would watch a couple of episodes until it was time to leave.  When she finally went back to Florida she said she was going to buy the DVD set for herself.  She said she loved the show and found the characters all very likeable and believable, and enjoyed the interactions between them very much.  This show is so good one has no doubt that people will like it.  I never had any at all, it was just a matter of getting her to watch one episode.

reviewText: If you like dry, morbid humor, you will love DLM. This episode was particularly poignant. This is the first time we see the parents' marriage trajectory, and realize they were once a happy nuclear family living a very traditional life with apparent satisfaction. We see how that over time produces not only bitterness in their relationship, but depression and a generally negative outlook in their daughters.We also get a deeper insight into Daisy, beyond her self-presentation to the world. And we see a new side of some of the other characters as well. "Maybe we are all just temps," is the episode's key line. And in that realization of the ephemeral nature of our existence, within a context of recording the last thoughts of the dying "for posterity," we find the essence of human life. We are here but a short while, and when we die it is hardly original, nor in the DLM universe is it generally very happy in the end. Every joy is fleeting. And even death is just another assignment. Yet we can be there for each other, surround ourselves with people we love, and that is the redeeming possibility.Somehow they manage to make all that moroseness humorous and heartfelt. Great writing and great acting. This is my second time watching this series, and though it is more of a belly laugh the first time through, it never fails to entertain.

They give solid reasoning for why they didn't like the show, and fans come along and crucify them for it! Not fair.In all faireness I was blown away by this show; it wasn't horrible at all. It was great. A dark comedy, for sure, as the reapers make light of a situation in everyone's life that NO ONE wants to deal with. Everyone wants to avoid death somehow; reverse the aging process any way they can, either mentally or physically. Sure no one wants to die. But what I learned from this show is that not everyone really lives either. Like the main character, George, has said many times throughout the show that she regretted not living enough.I was expecting something along the lines ofSix Feet Under, like another reviewer said. Putting those 2 show is a no contest--SFU wins big! But Dead Like Me isn't that far behind. It made me laugh at times, and really think seriously about life, and I almost cried.The characters were great, and eventually grew on me. Interesting to see Rube (Mandy Patinkin) who I knew from those stupid drug commercials do something with his career (though I guess he did those commercials AFTER the show was cancelled). And Laura Harris from some Nickelodeon show I saw as a kid who replaced Rebecca Gayheart, was an added blessing. Wasn't too crazy about the corny music throughout the show, though, despite it being composed by Stewart Copeland. But I didn't let that hold me back. As the episodes went on it grew on me.A great show that I'm sad had to end. Look forward to seeing the second season soon.

reviewText: What do I like in this series? The new perspective: life starts (or could start in our world) after death for some people; good characters (see the details below), though the Mason character loses his flavour by the second season and Betty is lost in the fifth episode (the fourth on the second disk); and of course humour, which is sarcastic and sometimes morbid, but perfectly fits a sitcom.So, the characters:--George, most of the time rebelling against any authority but gradually recognises that human relationships are important.--Rube, the boss whom George often drives mad but takes a (fatherly) liking of the wild but at the same time extremely vulnerable girl. He tries to be a good and strong foreman with a sometimes abrasive manner.--Mason, the crazy and amoral English guy, a hapless fellow, who has drinking and drug problems, he has no luck with human relationships, lacks the ability to form any.--Roxy, the traffic warden, no-nonsense hard-working lady, who mostly manages to hide her emotions but it does not mean they don't exist.--Betty, the one who really enjoys being a grim reaper, it seems to be a vocation for her. She is genuinely nice to the would be dead and never lets them die without making them smile first.--Daisy (who stands in for Betty after she leaves), the blond one, egotistic, gets what she wants and first does not seem to care about other people's feelings, though she begins to learn something on this front.It's four stars because the last three episodes reek of financial constraints: loads of flashbacks and reminiscences. There are some good ideas and jokes, but all in all they seem to be last ditch efforts by a reserve crew after the real crew went on holiday.If you like this series you may enjoyWonderfalls - The Complete Series

reviewText: No need to summarize and repeat what you can read in a gazillion other places. But among parables about living, DLM ranks, to my mind at least, as one of the best I've seen. As a story writer myself, I find forced to admit that this is probably better than anything I could have cooked up myself. Which is a big admission.Joss Whedon (creator of Buffy, Angel and Firefly; a man I admire), if he's honest about it, will probably eating his Absurdist heart out (and if he isn't, he ought to be). DLM, despite its lack of the 'spectacular', or maybe because of it, makes its point(s) with clarity and, often, very touching poignancy. And with soul.It addresses that aspect of 'teen angst' that's not all about 'social acceptance' and the pitfalls of high-school life, but about the profound loneliness that accompanies the clarity of vision that comes upon one in a period of one's life where one is old enough to understand a great many things, but not yet too old to have had the wool pulled over one's eyes by the world and its necessities. And why doesn't everybody else understand it as well? It's so obvious, is it not? How can anybody miss it?DLM also deals with DEATH. Yes, I know that's pretty obvious, but this obviousness hides the truth that in our dealings with death, imagined or real, we define our position in and attitude to life. DLM's dealing with death is relentless and never lets off. Every episode leaves you with another perspective on the subject; and quite possibly with one that you might not actually have thought of.Take all that together and you have what might be the most powerful show of recent years. That despite this it sustains an equally unrelenting comedic charm is a testimony to so very, very good story-telling.

reviewText: Dead Like Me is a show about Grim Reapers and their job, taking souls.  George (the main character) is the newest formerly alive person to become a reaper after she's struck down by a toilet seat from the Mir Space Station.  While alive, George was an 18 year old, fresh dropout from college and is now stuck in deadend clerical job, until she comes face to face with a very hot and very fast falling toilet seat.As a Reaper, she joins the division that involves, Murder, Suicides, and other incidents.  Her co-workers in this particular division are Roxy, a tough as nails meter maid; Betty a funny/quirky woman that loves to live in the lap of luxury; Mason a Brit that has a penchant for all sorts of drugs as well as partaking in shady deals in order to suppliment his income; and then there's Rube, the boss for the division who hands out the days assignments, Rube is in charge of trying to keep the group out of trouble (especially the newbie George).Together, the reapers get their assignments, go out and collect souls from those who are supposed to die in order for them to keep from suffering the pain of their tragic death (and in some cases to prevent the damage done to them being reflected in the person's soul).  Along with the job of being a Reaper, they have to find a way to earn money, whether it be legal or illegal.  Since the group is made up of the undead, they still have to eat, drink, have clothes, and a place to sleep, since Reaping is a job that offers nothing in the line of compensation.This first season chronicles the wacky adventures and in most cases misadventures.  One of the coolest things about this show is by watching out for the deaths that come about.  Sort of like watching C.S.I. or Six Feet Under, the deaths are always strange/cool and some are even a little comical.I first saw the show after it was cancelled on the Sci-Fi channel.  After I purchased this DVD from Amazon, well, I was surprised at all the...shall we say colorful language that appears in the show.  Still, this show is hilarious and I would recommend it to everyone out there who wants a good laugh.

reviewText: If you haven't seen "Dead Like Me" and have a high tolerance for bad language, you owe it to yourself to check it out.  Apart from the fact that this was a Showtime series (and thus the "TV Ratings" gloves were off for the producers), this show is a one-two punch of being very entertaining...and sucking you in the more episodes you watch.  Halfway through series one the writing goes from "good" to "excellent" and the characters start to come into their own.If you're not familiar with the concept, this is as spoiler-free as I can make it:  when some people die, they don't get to "move on" to the hereafter.  Instead, they are called "Reapers", and they've been put in charge of being present when people die.  Living half in and half out of the real world, Reapers have to both tag the unfortunate for death (to release their souls) and guide the newly-departed souls into the beyond.  The show doesn't try to put any religious messages into the concept--instead, there's something amusing about the way they make reaping seem like yet another bureaucratic process that keeps the wheels of civilization turning.  The point isn't the reaping--the point is the characters, and that's why it's really interesting.It's a real pity this show only lasted two seasons (and a separate movie)--I have a feeling it could have gone a lot farther.  The comedy is grim and macabre, but not mean-spirited.  It's also not very gory.  The only drawback is that the placement of bad language can be jarring at times.
